text: What are some mid-career tips you’d offer to someone with 8-10 years of experience in their field?

elements.text: What are some mid-career tips you’d offer to someone with 8-10 years of experience in their field?

text:
• Work with a mentee. When done properly, mentor-mentee relationships are collaborative and both sides are exposed to fresh ideas.
• Never stop learning, either through Coursera or LinkedIn Learning or Udemy, etc. 
• If applicable, join ERGs at your company to broaden your network and visibility

elements.text: Work with a mentee. When done properly, mentor-mentee relationships are collaborative and both sides are exposed to fresh ideas.
Never stop learning, either through Coursera or LinkedIn Learning or Udemy, etc.
If applicable, join ERGs at your company to broaden your network and visibility

text: Thanks <@U031B8HB5FB>. My rates are typically much higher than this, but this is a unique situation to help me build up an editorial portfolio of work. Taking these writing assignments has also opened up the door to more lucrative marketing consulting projects.

elements.text: Thanks

. My rates are typically much higher than this, but this is a unique situation to help me build up an editorial portfolio of work. Taking these writing assignments has also opened up the door to more lucrative marketing consulting projects.

text: This might be specific to my ADHD-brain, but I let myself take an afternoon -- or a morning -- and just hyperfocus on one of my Big, Pointless Projects (things I enjoy just to do, not because the result will be meaningful).

elements.text: This might be specific to my ADHD-brain, but I let myself take an afternoon -- or a morning -- and just hyperfocus on one of my Big, Pointless Projects (things I enjoy just to do, not because the result will be meaningful).

text: Identify your strengths (if you haven't already) and leverage them like crazy. At this point in your career, you've probably tried a lot of things (willingly or not) and you know what makes you tick. Lean into them so that the work you do today and in the future is fulfilling and inspiring. If you manage a team, learn their strengths so that you can help them be energized by their work too.

text: <#CJ7QJ4WKB|-career-advice> Hello Folks! I hope I am posting in the right channel here. I am a content writer and have been working over Upwrok for over a decade now (thats basically my entire school and college tenure). For some reason I never pursued high paying job, and I am trading hours for $$ which is pretty frustrating and demotivating now. I have a diverse set of skills because during the 10+ years I worked as a VA and Writer, both. But the clients I connect with are often in the lower middle category.  I want to move up in the game and meet my goal of making 3000 usd a month! This would be a dream come true for me. But I am at a loss of what to do. I dont wanna email existing clients with higher rates because I know they wont raise the price. So where can I look for better remote positions? Besides here :) I am following the jobs that Jimmy shares here. Also what should I add to my portfolio, that would connect me with high end clients. I am a content writer, have also done project management and wordpress frontend development a lot. So these three are my core areas :)

Besides here :) I am following the jobs that Jimmy shares here. Also what should I add to my portfolio, that would connect me with high end clients. I am a content writer, have also done project management and wordpress frontend development a lot. So these three are my core areas :)

text: How are your front end dev skills? Content marketing for agencies that produce dev content is a pretty well paying job IMHO. I can point you to some agencies if you like.

elements.text: How are your front end dev skills? Content marketing for agencies that produce dev content is a pretty well paying job IMHO. I can point you to some agencies if you like.

text:
If something is potentially going to be abused or is being abused, consider whether it makes sense to offer guidance about that teamwide — agnostic of the people. (Not for everything, of course. That’s why managers exist — to exercise good judgment.)

For example, when I built content operations from scratch at NerdWallet, I anticipated that we’d need to be clear about possible plagiarism, as well as someone potentially reusing parts of content they’d previously written. In case of the former, we specified that we’d fire violators. It was an absolute deal-breaker. In the case of the latter, we specified the maximum percentage of previously written copy (meaning written by THAT writer). For example, if you reused a bit explaining the prime rate or such, such copy could form only a maximum of X percent of any new piece.

In parallel with doing something like the above, I suggest that your conversation with the individual start with your asking Qs about why you’re seeing X happen. Open-ended Qs tend to work better, because you can avoid being accusatory and you can learn more. For example, maybe the person is burned out and that’s a bigger issue than, hey, would you please stop doing X?

When you ask open-ended Qs, you leave room for the person to give you material to double-click into.

By contrast, the narrower the questions or points you start with, the more likely you are to miss something significant. The less likely you can support someone to be (or to become) their best selves, which is best for them, your team and your company.

Plus, we’re all humans and communicating well can help build rapport and trust.

In parallel with doing something like the above, I suggest that your conversation with the individual start with your asking Qs about why you’re seeing X happen. Open-ended Qs tend to work better, because you can avoid being accusatory and you can learn more. For example, maybe the person is burned out and that’s a bigger issue than, hey, would you please stop doing X?

When you ask open-ended Qs, you leave room for the person to give you material to double-click into.

By contrast, the narrower the questions or points you start with, the more likely you are to miss something significant. The less likely you can support someone to be (or to become) their best selves, which is best for them, your team and your company.

Plus, we’re all humans and communicating well can help build rapport and trust.

text:
1. Pick various people who know you and your work well, people whose judgment you trust, who have different thinking than yours and ask them what they think your highest and best use might be careerwise. Ideally, these are progressive big thinkers, visionaries who AREN’T in your domain.
That doesn't mean do necessarily whatever they suggest. It's to potentially broaden your horizons, see things you might not.

2. In parallel, tap leaders in your domain who know the landscape well and get their POV on what will unfold in the next decade or so. That's so you can make better informed career decisions, come up with stronger strategic thinking. Note: You don't necessarily need to know such folks; you can consume their content about such thinking.

3. Whether you're job hunting or not, keep track of the job market, the compensation landscape. If you don't already do this, you should catch up. That's because the market keeps evolving and the only way to make informed career decisions related to that is to keep track. That includes what's in demand, what's starting to emerge, who your competition is for jobs and how you stack up, what skills you might need to build or strengthen.

Remember that career strategy should be macro AND micro. If not, you can't see the forest and trees.

I also suggest continuously leaning into discomfort. Dare to suck at new things. If you do that consistently, not only will you build new skills, you'll also become braver about taking risks, with proportionate potential rewards.
